titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.30 (19 July-26 July 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 30. Mercurius Publicus, COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence: WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order. From Thur≈øday July 19. to Thur≈øday July 26. 1660.
Whitehal.
div.p: HIs Maje≈øty ≈øince his Return having touch'd for the Evil near 1700 per≈øons, and there being at pre≈øent above 1000 more in London come from ≈øeveral Parts attending for the ≈øame, his Majesty is graciou≈øly plea≈øed so di≈øpatch all that are already come, and (for ≈øeveral weighty rea≈øons) re≈øolves to defer the re≈øt to a more ≈øea≈øonable opportunity.

We are therefore by His Majesties Command to give notice hereof, That none of his good Subjects may engage them≈øelves (till further Order) ‚Ä¢ an chargeable and unnece≈ø≈øary Iourneys. And we are further to give notice, That all from the Countries now attending in London the Cure of the Evil, do repair to Mr. Knight his Maje≈øties Chyrurgion, who lives in great
Bridges-≈øtreet at the Sign of the Hare in Covent Garden, on Tue≈øday and Thur≈øday next being the 24. and 26. of this in≈øtant July, when and where they ≈øhall receive Tickets for the Wedne≈øday and Friday, which two da ‚Ä¢ s his Maje≈øty is plea≈øed to ≈øet apart for this ≈øo pious and charit ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ le Work.

div.head:
St. Iago de la Vego in the I≈øland of Iamaica,
April 7.
div.p: The Negro's (of whom we daily reduce ≈øome to obedience) being taken, become our good friends, and ≈øerviceable to us in what they are capable: Colonel Ty≈øon was lately commanded ‚Ä¢ orth with eighty Officers and ≈øouldiers, and twenty one Negro's (who are very dexterous in catching the enemy after they are beaten‚ñ™ who after a tedious march over the mountains, found Don Chri≈øtopher lying in a Morro≈øs with 133 in Arms with him‚ñ™ commanded by an old Souldier of Spain, who had double pay allow'd him, and was to ≈øucceed the Spani≈øh General; in our fa ‚Ä¢ ling on, this Major received a wound by a Lance in his belly, of which he died in two houres; but their General Don Chri≈øtopher being too nimble for us, ≈øaved him≈øelf by flight. The Officers which were took pri≈øoners, and the Commi≈ø≈øioners that came in to treat for their General, confe≈ø≈øed there were about ≈øixty Officers and Souldiers ≈ølain. Thence the Party march'd to the Cherero≈øe at the Sea ≈øide, in order to the ≈øei≈øing a ≈øhip which the Spaniards had formerly taken from us, and did now monethly ≈øupply them with provi≈øions from Cuba, ≈øuch as Ca≈ø≈øader bread, ≈øweet-meats, Chocolates, and other conveniences. The ≈øecurity of this Ve≈ø≈øel was ≈øo well managed by Scouts, that there was no taking her by Land without them: We therefore fir≈øt lay in wait for the Scouts, whom when we had took in ≈øeveral parties, and made our own, in eleven daies time we took the ≈øhip, with twenty Officers and Souldiers in her.

And now (according to promi≈øe) we give you a Li≈øt of his Highne≈øs the Duke of Yorks Regiment, whereof very many, if not mo≈øt (by the plea≈øure of his Highne≈øs, (as well as his Grace the Lord General) are ≈øtill continued in their place, whom therefore we ≈øhall only name.

list.item: Sir Allen Ap≈øl ‚Ä¢ y (a gentleman of known merit for his intellectuals, as well as his courage and loyalty, which have made him eminently of his Maje≈øties hou≈øhold) is Captain Lievtenant to his Highne≈øs.
George Court ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y Quarterma≈øter.
Thomas Vi≈øcount Falconberge is Colonel under his Highne≈øs, and Captain of a Troop.
Charles Be ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øys Lievtenant.
Iohn B ‚Ä¢ lla≈ø≈øys Coronet.
Iohn Woodward Quarterma≈øter.
Anthony Buller (formerly a Colonel in the We≈øt-Indies) is a Captain.
Rich. Dounton Lievtenant.
Hugh Stukely Coronet.
Allen Wharton Quarterma≈øter.
Thomas Heward, ≈øon to the Earl of Berk≈øhire (as well pleas'd to command one of his Highne≈øs Troops as formerly his own Regiment, wherein he never expre≈øs'd the lea≈øt want of skill or courage.)
Hugh Brad≈øhaw Lievtenant.
Edward Sanders Coronet.
Chri≈øtopher Hull Quarterma≈øter.
Captain Iohn Sydenham (≈øon to Sir Ralph Sydenham, who hath manife≈øted his courage in France as well as England) commands a Troop.
William Noy Lievtenant.
George Collingwood Coronet.
Tho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Cooper Quarterma≈øter.

Sir Iohn Talbot (a Member of this pre≈øent Parliament,
as well as of that Noble hou≈øe of Shrewsbury) commandeth one of his Highne≈øs Troops.
Rich. Beke Lievtenant, Bacon Coronet, Nic. Lampon Quarterma≈øter.

div.p: Next be plea≈øed to take a Li≈øt of the Officers of his Highne≈øs the Duke of Gloce≈øter's Regiment.

list.item: His Highne≈øs Troop is commanded by M. Phil. Howard, ≈øon to the Earl of Berkshire.
Simon Mu≈øgrave (we need not tell you what family he i ‚Ä¢ of) is Coronet, Francis Moore is Quarterma≈øter.

Sir Ralph Knight (one who≈øe name became his Honour, upon his Maie≈øties happy return, wherein his endeavours were very u≈øeful) is Colonel, Tho. Bourne Lievtenant, Rich. Hooker Coronet, Ralph Dawe Quarterma≈øter.
Phil. Pri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e (very eminent for his manhood) is Major, William Hodgkin≈øon Lievtenant, Ant. Mitchell Coronet, Chri≈øt. Mallock Quarterma≈øter.
Tho. Co ‚Ä¢ l≈øon, Captain, Ed Au≈øtin Lievtenant, Robert Brownlow Coronet, James Crafis Quarterma≈øter.

Henry Ogle Captain, Tho. Ogle Lievtenant, Tho. Ogle Coronet, Lancelot S ‚Ä¢ rut ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Quarterma≈øter.
William Goodwin (who hath done good ≈øervice both at Sea and Land) is Captain.
Sir Hugh Middleton (≈øon of Sir VVilliam Middleton) impri≈øoned and plundered by the Rump, not ambitious of great command, but to do his Maie≈øty and his Highne≈øs ≈øervice is Lievtenant.
John Ball a Coronet, Fran Su ‚Ä¢ ley Quarterma≈øter.

div.p: Wi ‚Ä¢ h the≈øe Regimen ‚Ä¢ s we will take in the Ca≈øtle of St. Mawes in Cornwall, now under the command of Sir Richard Vivi ‚Ä¢ n Gent. of the Privy Chamber to his Maie≈øty, a per≈øon that hath remained un≈øhak ‚Ä¢ n in his loyalty in the mid≈øt of all his ≈øufferings.

We can give you but a thin account of Per≈øons committed to Cu≈øtody ≈øince our la≈øt: For the Black-rod hath but one Pri≈øoner more who≈øe name is Partington, not Portington, who was ≈øo couragious and loyal in his Maje≈øties ≈øervice, e≈øpecially at Pontefract, and other places in the north.
This day was pre≈øented to his Sacred Maje≈øty an Addre≈øs from the Governours and Commanders of the Ca≈øtle of the ancient City of Che≈øter.

body.head: To his mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, King CHARLES the Second, our mo≈øt gracious Soveraign.
The humble Addre≈øs of the Officers in the Ca≈øtle of Che≈øter, in the name of them≈øelves, and of the Souldiers of that Garri≈øon.
body.p:
WIth ≈øuch a thankful acknowledgement of the goodne≈øs of God in ≈øetling your Sacred Maje≈øty on the Throne of your Ance≈øtors, as becomes good Chri≈øtians and loyal Subjects, we renew in the≈øe rude lines the humble tendry of our bounden duty, wherein we continue to own your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty for our undoubted Soveraign Lord and King, hereby ≈øeconding our fir≈øt actings, wherein we, as ≈øoon as other Garri≈øons, freely yeilded our ≈øelves to follow (as duty did bind us) the Noble example of his Excel ‚Ä¢ ency the Lord General, under who≈øe au≈øpicious conduct that great breach our ≈øins had made, is happily made up again: And your Maje≈øty having given us ≈øo many ≈øignal tokens of your admirable virtue and goodne≈øs in your gracious Declaration ≈øet forth before you came into your Kingdomes, your pious Proclamation again≈øt Debauchery, and vertuous deportment ≈øince you came into your Imperial City, we find ≈øo much cau≈øe to believe that you will become another I ‚Ä¢ ≈øiah, in re≈øtoring the Wor≈øhip of God, ≈øetling the Church in peace after ≈øo long a time as ≈øhe hath ≈øit mourning with torn garments upon her, as our hearts rejoyce in expectation to ≈øee ≈øuch a compleat ≈øettlement of peace and truth, as the Laws of God, and the good Laws of the Land require, hoping that a due re≈øtraint will be put to prophane≈øs, ≈øuper≈øtition, and libertini≈øm. La≈øtly, we ≈øhall not by the grace of God recede from our bounden duty, but remain your Maje≈øties loyal Subjects and faithful Souldiers, manife≈øting upon all occa≈øions our readine≈øs to hazard our lives for the maintenance of your Royal Per≈øon,
Crown and Dignity, expre≈ø≈øing our ≈øelves alwa ‚Ä¢ es your Maje≈øties mo≈øt loyal Subjects and obedient Servants.

div.p: But in Scotland are committed Sir James Steward Provo≈øt of Edinborough, of who≈øe good deeds we never told you, and fear we never ≈øhall; and Sir John Che ‚Ä¢ ≈øley, whom 'twas ea≈øier to make a Knight than make him good. The≈øe two were the eminent Remon≈øtrants again≈øt his Maje≈øty, but have thou≈øands to remon≈øtrate again≈øt them, now they are in Edinborough Ca≈øtle.

There are more to be committed if they did not di≈øappear, though ≈øome have the forehead to approach the Court in England, of which number is the Lai ‚Ä¢ d Swinton, one of Oliver Cromwell's Coun≈øellours and Judges, who of late (for≈øooth) would needs turn Q ‚Ä¢ aker, and hath rea≈øon to be ≈øo in earne≈øt, ≈øince he is now apprehended and committed to the Gate-hou≈øe.

To morrow the Imperial Forces are to march out of Holstein, and (as is reported) to have their quarters a≈ø≈øigned them, yet for ≈øome time, in the Dukedoms of Meklenburg and Pomerania, until they receive farther Order. They write from Lubeck, that the Ca≈øtle of Cronenburg in Sealand was to be re≈øtored to Denmark this week without fail: The Hollands Admiral was as yet taken up with the tran≈øportation of the re≈øt of the Swedi≈øh Forces, for Schonen, and it was ‚Ä¢ oped, that all Se ‚Ä¢ land would be very ≈øuddenly cleared of all the Swedes. Letter; from Riga intimate, that in the City of Mu≈øcovia there happened a ≈øudden and unexpected Fire, which con≈øumed about 6000 Hou≈øes. The
Victory obtained by the Poles again≈øt the Mu≈øcovites is confirmed from man places, and reported to the be≈øt advantage on the Poli≈øh ≈øide. I ‚Ä¢ is ≈øaid, that at Berge in Norway, there are likewi≈øe (through carele≈øne≈øs) 600. Hou≈øes, burne down to the ground.

div.head: From Dalmatia, June 17.
div.p: Although the Turks did Fately leave this Country, under pretence that they were f√¥rced to retire them≈øelves for the maintenance of their Mahomet, which gave us ≈øome hope that we ≈øhould be rid of the≈øe trouble≈øome gue≈øts; yet now we find our≈øelves quite deceived, in regard the Turks have not onely faced about, and with an addition of 12000. men, above their former number, as well Hor≈øe as Foot, over run this whole Country without oppo≈øition, but dare al≈øo to venture an approach to the fortified places and Cities of Zara, Sebenico, and Spal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ro, putting not onely to the ≈øword all they met with, but de≈øtroying all Hou≈øes and Villages with fire, with the≈øe threats, that their Ordnances and Artillery is ≈øuddenly to follow after them, which when come, they intend to imploy to reduce the≈øe fortified Cities. But they being well provided again≈øt all ho≈øtile attempts with men Ammunition and Victuals, they need not in the lea≈øt ‚Ä¢ ear the menaces of the Turks, however we mu≈øt expect with patience, what attempts they ≈øhall make again≈øt us.

This day was ≈øeven-night, his Imperial Maje≈øty arrived ≈øafely at G ‚Ä¢ ath, with his whole Court, and was received by ≈øome thou≈øands of Hor≈øe and Foot of the chief of that Country, all accourred in brave Liveries, many hundreds of Canons being di≈øcharged at his Maje≈øties entrance, and magnificent Arches o ‚Ä¢ Triumph erected; there were al≈øo mo≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re Flieworks, and artificial Conduits prepared, out of which Clacer and Whitewine ran in abundance. The Duke of M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n met his Imperial Maje≈øty ≈øome Leagues off, and accompanied him at his entrance.

Ye≈øterday the Ceremonies of doing homage to his Imperial Maje≈øty, were performed with the u≈øual ≈øolempnities in this place; But his Maje≈øty hath not been able to appear in publique with the States of the Country by rea≈øon of continual rains, whether or no his Maje≈øty will inu≈øt on his Journey towards Carinthia and Craine, is as yet undetermined. It ≈øeemeth the re≈øolution thereof doth depend on the event of the pre≈øent Hungarian tranfactions. Since the Imperial General de Souches pa≈ø≈øed the River of Theies, and advanced nearer the Turks, they are retreated.

The Mayor of Majorca Signeur Raphael della Gro≈øsiera, 58 years of age, hath lately been elected in the place of the decea≈øed Great-Ma≈øter of Malta. The differences betwixt the Vice roy of Naples, and the Arch-bi≈øhop of that place, Cardinal Filomarini, are compo≈øed by the indeavours of the Spani≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadour here re≈øident, whom the Pope hath given audience. But the Vicar of the Archbi≈øhop, who laid the excommunication on the ≈øaid Vice-roy again≈øt the Cardinals con≈øent, is to be depo≈øed.

div.head: Presburg in Hungaria, July 11.
div.p:
I am informed from Ca≈øcha ‚Ä¢
of the 3. in≈øtant, that ours have put a Garri≈øon into K ‚Ä¢ llo, Prince Barchai giveth out, that he cannot ≈øurrender Sacmar, except he ≈øhould thereby expo≈øe his native Country to eminent danger and utter ruine. The Turks are no wayes inclined to ≈øubject that place to the Emperour. The Grand Vizier of Buda hath been accu≈øed at the Ottoman Court, whence having lately received a Halter (the accu≈øtomed pre≈øent for offenders) he now endeavoureth to ≈øave him≈øelf by flight. The Prince≈øs Ragotzky is now at Patack, where the Count Ladi≈ølaus Ragotzky, with many Noblemen and Ladies, give her their attendance, they labour al≈øo to have provi≈øion made for the Forces of his Imperial Maje≈øty, which ≈øhe conde≈øcends unto.

div.head: Adverti≈øements of Books newly Printed and Publi≈øhed.
div.p: ‚òû The Fourth Volume of Clelia, that Excellent Romance. Written by Mon≈øieur De Scudery. Sold by Humphrey Mo≈øeley at the Princes Arms in St. Pauls Churchyard, and Tho: D ‚Ä¢ ing at the George in Fleet≈øtreet, near St. Dun≈øtans Church.
A Congratulatory Poem on the Miraculous and Glorious Return of Charls the Second. By Alexander Broom.
God ≈øave the King; or a Sermon of Thank≈øgiving, for His Maje≈øties happy Return to His Throne. By William Walwyn, B. D. and ≈øometimes Fellow of St. Johns Colledge of Oxon.

Jews in America, or, Additional Probabilities, that tho≈øe Indians are Judaical. By Tho. Thorowgood, S. T. B. One who ≈øub≈øcribed the Vindication ≈øuffered by the Engagement, never addre≈ø≈øed to any of the u≈øurping Powers. There is promi≈øed to it, an accurate di≈øcour≈øe of Mr. Elliot in New England, touching the origination of tho≈øe Nations.

„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Or, the true Pourtraiture of His Sacred Maje≈øty Charls the Second. In three Books; beginning from His Birth, 1630. unto this pre≈øent year, 1660. Wherein is interwoven a compleat Hi≈øtory of the High born Dukes of York and Gloce≈øter. By R. F. E≈øq an Eye-witne≈øs. All four ≈øold by Henry Broom at the Gun in Ivy-lane.
A brief Introduction to the skill of Mu≈øick. The third Edition enlarged. Sold by John Playford at his ≈øhop in the Inner Temple-gate.

div.head: Adverti≈øements.
div.p: JUly 22. 1660. ≈øtoln from Mr. Edward Sandford of Nortonmandile in the County of E≈ø≈øex, a white Gelding, between fifteen and ≈øixteen hands high, about eleven years of age, the hair off upon all four feet, ju≈øt above the Hoof, a little ≈øweld upon the left Leg behinde. If any can bring tidings thereof to Mr. Henry John≈øon Chyrurgeon, in Alder≈øgate-≈øtreet, or to the owner at his Hou≈øe in Nortonmanlile afore≈øaid, they ≈øhall be well rewarded for their pains.

MO≈øt excellent and approved Dentrifices to ≈øecur and clean≈øe the Teeth, making them white as Ivory, pre≈øerves from the Toothach; ≈øo that being con≈øtantly u≈øed, the parties u≈øing it, are never troubled with the Toothach: It fa≈øtens the Teeth, ≈øweetens the Breath, and pre≈øerves the Gums and Mouth from Cankers and Impo≈øthumes; and being beaten to powder, and drunk in Wine, or any other drink, is a good remedy for any Flux or Lask. Invented and made by Robert Turner, the onely Author of them, and are onely to be had at the Hou≈øe of Thomas Rookes, Stationer, at the Holy Lamb at the Ea≈øt-end of St. Pauls Church, near the School, in Sealed Papers.
Becau≈øe 'tis likely you'l have ≈øome fal≈øe report of a mutiny of the pri≈øoners in Norwich the 18. of July la≈øt, be plea≈øed to take this Relation from one who was pre≈øent.

According to the cu≈øtom of the Sheriffs Court in Norwich, Sheriff Lawrence ≈øent for ≈øome pri≈øoners over to an≈øwer to Actions. The pri≈øoners entred a Combination, abu≈øed the Jaylor, re≈øcue their fellows: (pretending 'twas a Cu≈øtom again≈øt Law) declaring they would make it a free Goale: The Sheriff goes him≈øelf, and ≈øeeing no rea≈øon or fair means would prevail, (and his partner Sheriff Wi≈øe being ab≈øent then at London, goes to Mr. Mayor and the Magi≈øtrates, complains of a Mutiny and Rio, (hoping by that means to reduce them, or have a more firm ground to u≈øe rigour, if need ≈øhould be.) The Magi≈øtrates not very willing to meddle, being a bu≈øine≈øs more proper to the Sheriffs; yet at length they ≈øend for four of the chief: Their an≈øwer is, They will not come, nor be trepann'd by Mr. Mayor. The Sheriff is required to go him≈øelf for them; which he doth, but Orders privately ≈øome Files of Mu≈øquettiers to fall in clo≈øe after him. Tho≈øe four, with ≈øome other, betake them≈øelves to a ≈øtrong Vault, and grow re≈øolute: but at length the pri≈øoners propound, to draw off the Souldiers, and refer their main point to Coun≈øel, and if Law, they would ≈øubmit. The Souldiers thought that Demand ≈øo rea≈øonable, as they ≈øcrupled to a≈ø≈øi≈øt, and became Interce≈ø≈øors; whereupon it was agreed: There were al≈øo ≈øome other de≈øperate parties of pri≈øoners in other rooms, The Sheriff informs the Mayor and Court (then ≈øitting) what was done; the Coun≈øel determines again≈øt the pri≈øoners, but they fall from their promi≈øe of appearing to an≈øwer.) The Sheriff propounds then to return and fall on them, and either fire upon them with powder and ≈ømall ≈øhot, or el≈øe (rather) to ≈ømother them out with wet Hay: This the Magi≈øtrates would not approve, but wave it at pre≈øent. Some two or three days after, the pri≈øoners fearing new matters again≈øt them, grew high, ≈øecure the Jaylor, and take away the Keys; the Sheriff forthwith requires aid of the Citizens, but mo≈øt of them ≈ølipt away:
But with ≈øome few, and part of a band of Souldiers, re≈øolve (after Proclamation) to break open the pri≈øon door, and at the ≈øame time ≈øcale two Garden walls on the back ≈øide of the pri≈øon; but the Mayor and Ju≈øtices coming in the mean while, after ≈øome mutual me≈ø≈øages, and promi≈øe of favour to their chief Captain (one Godfrey,) he opens the pri≈øon door, and comes forth; whereupon the re≈øt yeelded.

list.head: The Reader may take notice, That after ≈øeveral mature Debates concerning this Summer A≈ø≈øizes, His Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to ≈øet forth a Proclamation the 23 of this in≈øtant July, wherein, out of his Princely care that his loving Subjects may have timely notice of the alterations of the dayes, hath declared the ≈øeveral Prefixions given in by His Maje≈øties Ju≈øtices for holding the A≈ø≈øizes in the ≈øeveral Circuits, as hereafter follow; viz.

Su≈ø≈øex, Friday the Seventh of September, at Ea≈øt-Green≈øtead.

Norfolk, Saturday the Fifteenth of September, at the Ca≈øtle of Norwich.
City of Norwich, The ≈øame day at the New-Hall of the City of Norwich.

Gloce≈øter, Wedne≈øday the Twelfth of September, at Gloce≈øter.

Salop, Friday the Eight and twentieth of September, at Bridgnorth.
Stafford, Wedne≈øday the Third of October, at Stafford.
Lanca≈øter, Thur≈øday the Thirtieth of Augu≈øt, at Lanca≈øter.
We≈øtmerland, Thur≈øday the Sixth of September, at Appleby.
Cumberland, Monday the Tenth of September, at Carli≈øle.
Northumberland, Friday the Fourteenth of September, at the Ca≈øtle of Newca≈øtle upon Tine.
Newca≈øtle upon Tine, The ≈øame day at the Guild-Hall of the ≈øame Town.
Durham, Tue≈øday the Eighteenth of September, at Durham.
York Monday the Four and twentieth of Septemb. at the Ca≈øtle of York.
York City, The ≈øame day at the Guild-Hall of the ≈øame City.
Southampton, Monday the Third of September, at the Ca≈øtle of Winche≈øter.

div.p:
This day the Borough of Plymouth, as an expre≈ø≈øion of their unfeighned joy for his Maje≈øties happy re≈øtauration, pre≈øented by the hands of the Right Honourable Sir William Morris,
one of his Maje≈øties principal Secretaries of State, and Governor of Plymouth, Serjeant Maynard Recorder, Edm. Vowell, Sam. Trellany E≈øquires, and Timothy Al≈øop Alderman, an honorable pre≈øent of plate, which for the largene≈øs of the pieces, and curio≈øity of the work, was a noble pre≈øent, and was received very graciou≈øly by his Maje≈øty: Among≈øt the re≈øt was a Fountain carved with rare Art and curious Figures, out of which perfumed water was ca≈øt up twenty foot high, and had at the top thereof a curious Perfuming box, which at the ≈øame time i≈ø≈øued forth perfumed fire. His Maje≈øty, with ≈øeveral per≈øons of Honour, was plea≈øed to entertain him≈øelf with the ≈øight of it.

At the ≈øame time the City of Exeter, by the ≈øaid Sir William Morris, Tho. Bampfied E≈øq Recorder, Simon Snow Alderman, and Thomas We≈øtlake Town-Clark, as a pledge of their Congratulation of His ble≈ø≈øed Re≈øtauration, and an earne≈øt of their hearty affections, did pre≈øent his Maje≈øty with ≈øeveral parcels of rich plate to a very con≈øiderable value for the ma≈øs thereof.
All the per≈øons of both Corporations had the honour of his Maje≈øties Hand.

Serjeant Maynard having declared the affection of the ≈øaid City and Borough in a mo≈øt elegant pithy Speech, to which his Maje≈øty manife≈øted a particular application, the Serjeant being better heard here then when he forced his entrance into the Hou≈øe of Commons (after two moneths ≈øeclu≈øion) when tho≈øe horrid Regicides fell upon that bloody debate, where the Serjeant by Cromwel was divers times demanded to the Bar, as unable to bear the ≈øtrength and force of the Serjeants Arguments, when he pleaded ≈øo admirally for the Life of the King.

This day, ≈øome of the Clergy of the County of Lincoln, in the Name of the re≈øt, being brought into the Royal Pre≈øence by the Earl of Manche≈øter, pre≈øented an Addre≈øs to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, which His Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly
plea≈øed to accept with ≈øeveral expre≈ø≈øions of favour to the Pre≈øenters, giving them al≈øo the Honour to ki≈øs His Hand.

body.head: To the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Majesty. The mo≈øt humble Addre≈øs of the Mini≈øters in the County of Lincoln.
body.p: AMong all the great calamities which God mo≈øt ju≈øtly for our ≈øins hath brought upon us, ≈øince the fir≈øt commencing of our national di≈øtractions, none have made ≈øo deep impre≈ø≈øions of real ≈øorrow upon our hearts, as the barbarous inhumanity Acted upon your Royal Father of ble≈ø≈øed memory, by certain wicked and deceitfull men: The remembrance of which, as it doth renew our utmo≈øt abhorrency of the Act, ≈øo of all tho≈øe Je≈øuitical Principles, which under any pretence what≈øoever, have any tendency to the depo≈øing, and much more the murder of Kings.

After the lo≈øs of the be≈øt de≈øerving King the world could then boa≈øt of, which was attended with the voice of bla≈øphemy uttered by our enemies again≈øt the true Religion, becau≈øe ≈øome who did profe≈øs it, had ≈øtained her beauty with their bloody hands. Gall was added to our wormewood by the forced exile of your Maje≈øty, during who≈øe ab≈øence abroad, we could hardly think our ≈øelves to be at home.

But God who comforteth tho≈øe who are ca≈øt down, gave us hope in the wonderfull pre≈øervation of your Maje≈øty at Worce≈øter, yea many ≈øupplications made for you by your faithfull people, and e≈øtabli≈øhment of your Royal heart with his grace, to re≈øi≈øt and overcome a great crowde of Temptations both on the right hand and on the left, by holding fa≈øt the true Ancient, Catholique and Apo≈øtolical Faith once delivered unto the Saints. The≈øe things were to us as the dawning of the day of Salvation, which God after a darke night of confu≈øion, hath now (not by an ordinary working of Providence) cau≈øed to ≈øhine upon us. And we have cau≈øe to believe
that he who hath ≈øubdued the power of the Enemy, will al≈øo ≈øubdue their hearts; that as your Maje≈øties return hath been accompanied with the cordial de≈øire and joy of the mo≈øt of your ≈øubjects; ≈øo your reign will be with the great love and full ≈øatisfaction of all. And this our confidence is more increa≈øed by your Maje≈øties gracious, charitable and healing Declaration of the fir≈øt of May, and your early Proclamation i≈ø≈øued again≈øt vicious, debauched and prophane per≈øons. For which, as we are always bound to prai≈øe God, ≈øo we do with all humble thankfulne≈øs, acknowledg your maje≈øties ≈øpecial grace and Princely favor. And what≈øoever our earne≈øt prayers to God, exhortations to our hearers, and dutifull ≈øubjection may po≈ø≈øibly contribute to the happine≈øs of your ≈øacred per≈øon and government; we ≈øhall with all alacrity and faithfulne≈øs perform, be≈øeeching him by whom Kings reign, to encrea≈øe your graces, pre≈øerve your health, prolong your days, and e≈øtabli≈øh the Crown upon your head.

It was pre≈øented by the hands of the Reverend and mo≈øt Learned Doctor Saunder≈øon His Maje≈øties Profe≈ø≈øor of Divinity at Oxon, accompanied with that worthy Gentleman Sir Thomas Meeres, and ≈øeveral of the Orthodox and Loyal Clergy, viz.

Mr. Wil. Lincolne.

Mr. Hen. Vaughan.
Mr Andrew Arnold.
Mr. Tho. Tro ‚Ä¢ t, &c.
And about 200. more, whom (onely for brevities ≈øake) we omit.

div.p:
The Gentlemen of the Artillery Company, having appointed ye≈øterday (the 24. of July) for an extraordinary Exerci≈øe of Arms in the Artillery ground, His H ‚Ä¢ ghne≈øs the Duke of York (their Commander in Chief) having notice thereof, came thither about four of the Clock in the afternoon, and fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øing through the Front of the Body (who were Four hundred compleatly habited) to a Tent
prepared for his Highne≈øs, he they on Foot marched to the Head of them, where that mo≈øt valiant and mo≈øt learned John Lord Lucas (after an Elegant ≈øhort Speech on his knees to his Highne≈øs) pre≈øented him with the Leading-≈øtaff of the Company, whereupon the Drums beat, with a very loud Acclamation of the Gentlemen in Arms. After ≈øilence was commanded, his Highne≈øs was plea≈øed to declare, how willingly he accepted of their offer, and would maintain all their Priviledges; then (throwing off his Cloak) he commanded them to march, him≈øelf on foot before them; and having led them about the ground, and drawn them up, he went to the Tent door, where he ≈øate while≈øt the Company marched by, plea≈øed to ≈øee ≈øuch a gallant Company. After that, they divided into two Bodies, the one commanded by the Lord Lucas, and the other by Major General Sir Edward Ma≈ø≈øey; the great Guns playing, they immediately fell to skirmi≈øh, fir≈øt by Forlorne, afterwards in ≈øeveral figures. At His Highne≈øs departure, ≈øeveral Volleys were given. After his departure, the Bodies being joyned, the Lord Lucas acquainted them, That a Gentleman, a Member and Well-wi≈øher of the Company, had pre≈øented to them a Silver Partizan; for which (in the name and behalf of all) his Lord≈øhip gave the Donor thanks.

This day Jo≈øeph Payne E≈øq Major of the City and County of the City of Norwich, and Thomas Rant, and William Barneham, E≈øquires, Members of Parliament for the ≈øaid City; Chri≈øtopher Jay E≈øq Alderman Thomas Wi≈øe, one of the Sheriffs, Thomas John≈øon, Alderman, Francis Norris, Robert Bendi≈øh, Gent. and Thomas Bale≈øton, Town Clerk, and divers other Citizens of the ≈øaid City, were brought into the pre≈øence of His Maje≈øty, by the Lo ‚Ä¢ d Howard and Sir Horatio Town≈øend, accompanied with Sir John Holland, Sir Philip Woodhou≈øe, Sir Ralph Hare, and Sir William Doyley, with divers other E≈øquires and Gentlemen in the County of Norfolk; where the Major, and the re≈øt of the Citizens, pre≈øented His Maje≈øty with the Re≈øignation of the Fee-Farm Rents of the ≈øaid City, under the Common Seal of the ≈øaid City, amounting to One hundred thirty and two pounds eighteen ≈øhillings and three pence yearly, and One thou≈øand pounds in Gold, as a te≈øtimony of their thankfulne≈øs to God for His Maje≈øties ≈øafe return to the Government of His Kingdom, and of their loyalty and faithfulne≈øs to Him. And His Maje≈øty gave them a gracious reception, and was plea≈øed to confer the Honor of Knighthood upon the ≈øaid Thomas Rant and Jo≈øeph Payne, and gave the Honor of His hand to all that Company; and promi≈øed His con≈øtant Favor and Protection to the ≈øaid City.

Since the la≈øt, Col. Cooke (who formerly kept the Office of Trea≈øurers-Remembrancer of the Exchequer) is come under the Black Rod; but we forbear to ≈øay any thing of him, or any, who willingly ≈øurrender them≈øelves.

We are daily asked what's done in Scotland, by ≈øome who are troubled, that all is at quiet, and becau≈øe it is ≈øo, them≈øelves ≈øweat to beget pretty Tales of the Presbytery, Covenanters, &c. as if there were no difference betwixt 1640. and 1660. But twenty years will not make ≈øome men wi≈øer. You (ever for their ≈øakes) we will ≈øay and ≈øpeak truth, That His Maje≈øty hath given Admittance and Audiance to tho≈øe Per≈øonages, and others from Scotland, who came from Court highly ≈øatisfied with admiration of His Maje≈øties Wi≈ødom, Ju≈øtice, and Affection to His People. And if you hear any ≈øpeak otherwi≈øe, know them ≈øo ≈øuch as wi≈øh it ≈øo, becau≈øe it is fael≈øe: They take liberty to talk, but tho≈øe that ≈øcribble or print it, ere long may repent.
London, Printed by J: Macock, and Tho. Newcomb, 1660.
